monogr.title: A straunge foot-post : vvith a packet full of strange petitions. After a long vacation for a good terme
monogr.author: Nixon, Anthony

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: THe Persians were wont to keepe in their houses the Picture of an Epicure ouerladen with wine, and sleeping with meate in his mouth, that by the view of such an vgly fight they might learne to be moderate, and avoyd the like excesse. The Parthians also to make their young men learne and fall into detestation of the alluring inticements of wicked women, are said to keepe in their houses a young man blinde carued very curiously; besides whome, was adioyned the Picture of a Woman, of farre more excellent perfection then the Image of Pigmalion, hauing one hand in his pocket to picke his purse, and holding a knife in the other hand to cut his throat.

For eschewing the like enormities, I wish thee (Reader) in stead of the Persians Picture of an Epicure, and the Parthians Picture of an Harlot in thine house, to carry about thee this Packet in thy Pocket: Which being opened, will Present sufficient matter vnto thee that may both make thee weane thy selfe from wanton desires, and shun the misery that followes excessiue superfluity, as also escape many other detriments that accompany the contempt of aduised courses.

If any handling this Packe, or perusing it (as I doubt not but many will) shall by it be drawne to forsake some infectious humours that it opens vnto them, I shall be glad of the recouery such sicke Patients: If others (not tainted) with the like infirmities) shall onely looke on it, and laugh at it, and partly like it, the end of my labours haue a condigne counterpoise: Farewell.
